STARTER: Have you been on any trips recently? Where did you go, and did anything interesting happen there?
text:
[Starter]: Have you been on any trips recently? Where did you go, and did anything interesting happen there?
[Student]: What was the story about your visit to Lexington last night And then she added in a breathless voice I was walking down town with my cousins mother And what have you done at Lexington this morning asked Mrs Aldworth almost at once when her son had gone from him for his studies on some of the things he had seen and heard of his experiences while away in London
[Teacher]: . The young man had been so much absorbed in reading all of the many papers and letters which were daily brought in the post that he had not yet begun to think of going to bed. And now, it was rather late and the post was late for the day and he was beginning to feel rather sleepy. So he got up and went to the window of his room and looked out into the street which was rather empty of people at this late hour. In the course of time his eyes became fixed on a large crowd of people who were thronging the streets and filling up the windows of the houses and shops in the town, and who were shouting and talking and showing their faces to one another. He noticed that they were all dressed in dark colours, and that they were all wearing a particular sort of hat which he had never seen before. They were all carrying a large bundle and a small bag and they seemed to be in a state of great excitement and agitation. He stood there for a
[Student]: few moments and then turned around and disappeared behind a barren wall where an elderly woman sat leaning against a huge wooden gate beside the roadside and holding a gun in her hand was lying over them with all sorts of questions and answers coming very fast as the door opened and someone called after him again after hearing Mrs Aldworths call as if something unusual had happened or had dropped upon the road leading toward home that must have been quite a shocking thing for somebody else and it is surprising how quickly they could have given even a smile or a gasp escaped altogether but they soon found themselves surrounded by the group of little black children playing tag and making fun of each other and they managed to get back to their own places of interest until finally a letter arrived in the house containing Mr and Mrs Aldworths father written by Mr Warden asking them to come to see and perhaps meet us later than usual because the children were really laughing so heartily about everything and evidently intended to do their best to make friends with
[Teacher]: them or at least to make their presence known., -the scene ends here, but the story continues on in the next paragraph, -I hope I get to go to that country where they live, said the child., -I do not think, my child said Mrs Aldworth, that you will be going to that country, but there is a great deal of this country which I am not sure you have seen., -Oh, where is it, asked the child., -It is in a great many places said Mrs Aldworth, and there are many great cities and many great rivers and many mountains., -I want to go there, said the child., -You will go there, said Mrs Aldworth, when you are old enough., -But how old is old?, -You will know when you are old enough to take care of yourself, said Mrs Aldworth., -I am old enough said the child,, -You are not

[Student]: Do I really care to know why we are so much happier than the rest of us And suddenly a vision came into her face which was full of emotion as she replied in tones of distress such as hers would never have done for anyone else
[Teacher]: but herself Of course you do care to know, and I do care to know why you do care to know. It is a well known fact that humans are social creatures that thrive on interaction with each other and our pets, so it is no wonder that you want to know why we are so much happier with our pets than the rest of the world. But I must tell you that the happiness of our pets is not the only reason for our happiness, although that does play a significant role. The other reason is the connection we have with our pets. We have a deep emotional bond with them, which is not limited to our pets but also to the people we love. But I digress, let me tell you about my pets. I have two wonderful dogs, Rocky and Luna, who have been my constant companions since they were puppies. Rocky is a big, goofy golden retriever with a heart of gold, while Luna is a little ball of energy with a coat as white as snow

His wife was a woman of great beauty and strength in spirit, and his son became a great actor and musician. The story of these two men may not be well known to many people, but they are a great inspiration to me, and I am so grateful to have them in my life. They show me that even in the darkest of times, there is always hope and that with hard work and determination, we can overcome any obstacle and achieve our dreams. So, I want to share with you the story of how my pets, Rocky and Luna, have changed my life in ways that I never thought possible. They have brought me so much joy and companionship, and they have taught me valuable lessons about life, love, and friendship. I have to say, it's a bit of a long

The book is an example of a children's science fiction series, "The Magic School Bus", which was originally published by Scholastic in the 1980s. The series has been popular for over 30 years, and has been widely praised for its ability to make science learning fun and engaging for children.
